text: An organic compound has the empirical formula \(CH_{2}\). If its molar mass is 42\(gmol^{-1}\), what is its molecular formula?  (C = 12.0, H = 1.0)
explanation:
Given the molecular formula, \(CH_{2}\).
The empirical formula will be \((CH_{2})n\)= 42
\((12+(2\times1))n =42\)
⇒ \(14n =42\)
n = 3, hence the empirical formula is \(C_{3}H_{6}\)

text: What is the mass of solute in 500\(cm^{3}\) of 0.005\(moldm^{-3}\) \(H_{2}SO_{4}\)? ( H = 1, S = 32.0, O=16.0)
explanation:
Using
n = cv where n = no of mole, c = molar concentration(mol/dm3) and v = volume( dm3)
volume =  500\(cm^{3}\) = 0.5dm3, c = 0.005\(moldm^{-3}\)
number of mole(n) = c x v = 0.5 X 0.005 = 0.0025mol.
but n = \(\frac{mass}{ molar mass}\) =  0.0025 = \(\frac{mass}{ 98}\) (where 98g/mol is the molar mass of H2SO4)
mass of H2SO4 = 0.0025 x 98 = 0.245g.

text: Consider the following reaction equation: \(2HCl + Ca(OH)_{2} \to CaCl_{2} + H_{2}O\). What is the volume of 0.1\(moldm^{-3}\) HCl that would completely neutralize 25\(cm^{3}\) of 0.3\(moldm^{-3}\) Ca(OH)\(_{2}\)?
explanation:
Using the formula, \(\frac{C_{A}V_{A}}{C_{B}V_{B}} = \frac{N_{A}}{N_{B}}\), we have
\(\frac{0.1 \times V_{A}}{0.3 \times 25} = \frac{2}{1}\)
\(V_{A} = \frac{0.3 \times 25 \times 2}{0.1 \times 1}\)
\(V_{A} = 150cm^{3}\)
